Originally on this trip I had intended to paddle down the gorge by kayak, unfortunately the river being too low at this time of year forced me to rely on leg power alone. This was unfortunate because not only am I getting on a bit now but some of the woodland clinging to the sides of this fabulous gorge are virtually inaccessible by any other means. In all I spent three days exploring the more accessible parts and viewing an amazing amount of wildlife two Badgers,two foxes,one grey Squirrel and numerous Roe deer to be precise. Having never seen a Badger in my life before, to practically fall over two in the twilight was quite an experience I can tell you,a bit like buses really, you wait a lifetime for one and two come along at once!

Despite the impression the border countryside might give to the casual observer; that of being a relatively well-wooded area replete with It's own share of ancient sites similar to other regions in the UK. The truth is in fact virtually the polar opposite, what you see is almost wholly a result of centuries of intensive management and exploitation, any natural woodland having long ago been cleared or relegated to steep slopes, ravines and rocky ground unfit for agriculture or sheep. On this trip my aim was to get a closer look at one of the few remaining survivors, an ancient wood clinging to the steep slopes above the river Tweed near Scotts view; a view made famous by sir Walter Scott.

Having had for many years an intense fascination with ancient woodland,particularly those least affected by human activity, ie sites most resembling what Oliver Rackham (author on the subject} termed 'Wildwood' I find myself now constantly on the lookout {hence Blogging) for ways to contact those with a similar passion to share info' with. Unfortunately I have found that most writing on the subject tends to focus on areas with a long history of interference by man, which although fascinating in itself tends to overlook my own particular interest, an interest I can directly attribute to another author: Robert Holdstock. Holdstocks book 'Mythago wood' set me on a course I've never regretted taking; that of identifying and exploring the most natural woods in these islands, for although no doubt incredibly rare and tiny in comparison to Holdstocks I assume wholly fictional 'Mythago' I'm convinced that such places do exist. To date the nearest approximation to such a wood I've come across grows on a small island in the middle of a bog near Tullamore in Ireland (this wood is mentioned in one of Oliver Rackhams books, the title of which escapes me).The trees here are truly magnificant, with Ivy covered giant Oaks leaning every which way but straight, while others long dead loom like Mammoths in the gloom of the interior. Well, thats my reason for Blogging I hope it makes some kind of sense.
